message_1: A company wants to determine the average age of its employees. They randomly selected 50 employees out of their total 500 employees and found out their ages. Based on this sample, they found an average age of 35 years with a standard deviation of 5 years. Find the 95% confidence interval for the true average age of all employees in the company.
message_2:
To find the 95% confidence interval for the true average age of all employees in the company, we will use the formula for the confidence interval of a sample mean:

CI = x̄ ± Z * (σ / √n)

where:
CI = confidence interval
x̄ = sample mean (average age)
Z = Z-score (for a 95% confidence interval, the Z-score is 1.96)
σ = standard deviation of the sample
n = sample size

In this case, we have:
x̄ = 35 years
σ = 5 years
n = 50 employees

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

CI = 35 ± 1.96 * (5 / √50)

First, calculate the standard error (σ / √n):

Standard error = 5 / √50 ≈ 0.7071

Now, calculate the margin of error (Z * standard error):

Margin of error = 1.96 * 0.7071 ≈ 1.3859

Finally, calculate the confidence interval:

CI = 35 ± 1.3859
CI = (35 - 1.3859, 35 + 1.3859)
CI ≈ (33.6141, 36.3859)

So, the 95% confidence interval for the true average age of all employees in the company is approximately (33.6141, 36.3859) years.
